{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2961565,"name":"Chadfrom7226","username":"Chadfrom7226","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chadfrom7226/{size}/113429_2.png","created_at":"2021-07-12T16:52:19.356Z","cooked":"

Hey all,

Our team is looking to create a T-shirt cannon robot.

I‚Äôm in the middle of planning out the pneumatic system and I had a few questions:

  1. What are teams using for their low-pressure tank? I know from reading some older CD posts that teams typically do High pressure tanks ‚Üí low pressure tank, where the low pressure tank has a high flow 1" outlet for connecting to the tube. I think I saw someone made one out of PVC, I have also seen tons of people advocating against PVC. I see online that schedule 40 PVC is rated to 280 PSI for a 2" diameter tube. I‚Äôd rather not make anything if there is something available for use. I am considering getting an aluminum clippard tank, then modifying it to have a 1" npt on one of the sides Part# AVT-24-6 . Of course, anything modified or made will have to be pressure tested.

Also, what volume should I use for the low pressure tank?

  1. What capacity are teams using for their High pressure tanks? I was thinking of using an HPA aluminum paintball tank because they‚Äôre cheap, high pressure, I assume they‚Äôre decently durable if people use them for paintball, and they‚Äôre pretty light weight so we can have a few on hand and quickly swap them out. I was looking at a Tippmann 48 cubic inch, 3000psi tank. Anyone think I‚Äôll have any problems? Online says that capacity can do about 800-1000 paintball shots. I assume I could probably get about 50 T-shirt cannon shots with it, which would be a sweet spot. It would depend, of course, on the volume for the low pressure tank in #1

  2. What large-diameter hoses are people using? From what I read I should be using about a 1" npt hose. I see some on mcmaster, but they are 1" npt to a 3/4" diameter hose. Will this be enough to launch a T-shirt or do I need bigger?

  3. We are looking to do a revolver-style cannon. How can I mate the barrel to the hose? A long while ago, I read someone had about a 1/2" gap between the end of the hose and the the barrel and it shot fine. Does this sound good enough or should I try to design some sort of seal?

Thanks in advance for any advice! It would be nice to actually build some sort of robot this year.

Now after doing some research, I am quite a bit confused.

Here is a scuba pony tank: Zeagle 20 cu ft Pony Bottle System with Razor Regulator - House of Scuba
That one is 20 cubic feet.

Here is a 62/3000 aluminum paintball tank: 62ci / 3000psi Aluminum Compressed Air Tank - Black ‚Äì HK Army Clothing
That one is 32 cubic inches.

Those two look to be around the same size. How is one 62 cubic inches, and the other is 20 cubic feet? 1 cubic foot = 1728cubic inch. There is no way the scuba tank is 5574x bigger than the paintball tank.

I have to be missing something here‚Ä¶

Edit: Looks like Scuba tanks are rated for total air volume whereas paintball tanks are rated for liquid volume

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2021-07-12T20:16:06.077Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":182,"readers_count":181,"score":46.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":395022,"topic_slug":"t-shirt-cannon-help-maths","display_username":"Chadfrom7226","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":3,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.houseofscuba.com/product/tank45.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Zeagle 20 cu ft Pony Bottle System with Razor Regulator - House of Scuba","clicks":14},{"url":"https://hkarmy.com/collections/aluminum-compressed-air-tank/products/62ci-3000psi-aluminum-compressed-air-tank-black?variant=39335234502726","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"62ci / 3000psi Aluminum Compressed Air Tank - Black ‚Äì HK Army Clothing","clicks":8}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20021,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/t-shirt-cannon-help-maths/395022/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2961575,"name":"Gus Michel II","username":"GeeTwo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/geetwo/{size}/120962_2.png","created_at":"2021-07-12T18:14:02.251Z","cooked":"

A cubic foot is 1728 cubic inches. And as you noted above, the scuba tanks are sized by scfm (air at sea level), not actual tank volume.

On PVC: the problem with plastic tanks isn‚Äôt that they can‚Äôt be rated for the pressure. The problem is that if the tank ruptures, plastic will usually shatter whereas metal will tear. When storing water, it‚Äôs not such a big deal because water doesn‚Äôt compress, so it doesn‚Äôt store nearly as much energy, so it doesn‚Äôt make pieces fly as much as air. Consider this in reverse: create a sufficiently sturdy cylinder with piston with a 1 square inch cross section. Let‚Äôs make it 30 inches tall.

  1. Fill it with water. Put a 3000# weight on the piston. It will drop less than a quarter of an inch, so the water is storing less than 60 foot pounds of energy.
  2. Fill it with air. Put a 3000# weight on the piston. It will drop quickly most of the way down. As the heat dissipates, the weight will continue to fall, stabilizing at less than a quarter inch from the bottom. Even given how much energy left as heat, that air is clearly storing MUCH more energy.

For paintball vs scuba, I can‚Äôt see why the tank style would be much difference, but the regulator would. Scuba regulators are in the sub-200psi (usually 125-160) output range, so you can use a fairly standard secondary regulator to charge your secondary tank. It looks like the paintball regulator puts out 800psi, so you‚Äôll have some additional cost or parts there.

3946 uses a tank which is perhaps 6-8" in diameter and 30" long - it‚Äôs enough for several shots; it wouldn‚Äôt have to be this large. I‚Äôm not sure where the tank came from, but it has one large pipe (1-1/2" NPT, I believe) and several smaller ones. If you can find 4" or similar steel pipe 30-36" long, and put an end cap on one end and reducer fittings on the other, you should have enough air for at least one shot. After a few redesigns, 3946 ended up not using any large hoses, but direct pipe from tank to barrel, and we actually rotated the tank (and in some cases the whole robot) to aim in azimuth. For altitude, fixing it at 45 degrees works just fine; you can adjust range by varying pressure, valve open time, or both.

On a valve, be sure to get one rated for AIR pressure (same reasons as the PVC tank). Also be sure to get one actuated with a solenoid, regularly closed. Motor actuated valves are too slow and will probably result in dribble shots. As the valve will be closed most of the time, a normally open solenoid will use more electricity and generate more heat, likely burning itself out.

I‚Äôve never done a revolver-style. 1/2" gap sounds wasteful, though.

Don‚Äôt overlook CO2 as an option. A 5lb tank refill is 16 dollars and we get a lot of our refills donated. The small tank is easy to locate on a robot due to CO2 being in a liquid state when compressed in the tanks. It is also easy to transport (I can carry two with ease) and any welding shop can refill it on short notice.

Our cannon launches shirts using between 10 and 35 psi (10-15 for indoor assemblies and 25-35 for football games/parades). We use a large bore check valve that is forced open with a pneumatic cylinder to allow a full pressure release as quickly as possible. For a low pressure accumulator tank we use a steel well pressure tank. Being under 40 psi affords some luxuries that are very welcome to us.

Edit:. We use a 3/4 Parker Push Lok Plus hose and have been completely satisfied with it.

How many shots can you get with a 5lb tank of CO2? I was looking at CO2 tanks for paintball as well.

The tank will most likely be stored sideways in the robot and I left about 18" long and about 5" diameter for tanks. I am worried about CO2 being sideways because I‚Äôm pretty sure that‚Äôs what is in the compressed air bottles and I don‚Äôt want any liquid coming out, which is why I was looking at compressed air.

Thanks!

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2021-07-12T20:15:25.150Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":123,"readers_count":122,"score":34.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":395022,"topic_slug":"t-shirt-cannon-help-maths","display_username":"Chadfrom7226","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":22335,"username":"GeeTwo","name":"Gus Michel II","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/geetwo/{size}/120962_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20021,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/t-shirt-cannon-help-maths/395022/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2961587,"name":"Mentor FRC 2992, FTC 25619, past FTC 10337, FTC 14374","username":"msonnier","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/msonnier/{size}/199751_2.png","created_at":"2021-07-12T21:17:29.039Z","cooked":"

We use normal BBQ grill size ‚Äúoff the shelf‚Äù propane tanks (new + never filled w/ propane) from Home Depot etc., with the natural gas OPD check valve unscrewed from the tank (not easy ‚Äì heat it with a torch or similar to break the thread locker) and replaced with a 3/4" NPT pipe nipple and fittings. Threads are compatible.

In our configuration, we use 2 of these tanks in parallel, with separate regulators set to different pressures. There are parallel McMaster sourced 3/4" air hoses from the 2 tanks fed into parallel 3/4" (Amazon sourced / China made) solenoid valves. We combine the air output of solenoid valves into 1" pipe fed into rear of the barrel.

This configuration gives us 3 launch power options. With regulators set for about 40psi and 60psi on the 2 tanks, we can launch T shirts to lower part of football stands at our school (about 30-40 feet - firing only lower pressure solenoid), to the high end of stands right in front of us (about 80-100 feet - firing only the higher pressure solenoid), or to far reaches of far corner of stands (maybe 200 feet) firing both solenoids together. These ranges are tunable via regulator adjustment. We have tested the system up to regulator pressure of about 120psi on both tanks, which shoots a T-shirt about 300 feet (with properly rolled shirt and tight barrel fit). We get 2-3 shots out of these accumulator tanks before needing a recharge from our high pressure tank (scuba style tank ‚Äì actually using a firefighters air tank which is a bit smaller but similar).

Advantages:
‚Äì Different levels of shot power
‚Äì Tanks are MUCH cheaper than other alternatives we found (under $40 each) and rated for MUCH higher pressures (usually rated / tested to 600psi or more) than needed
‚Äì Readily available parts and fittings
‚Äì Uses 2 x 3/4" solenoids which are MUCH cheaper than 1" solenoid valves
‚Äì All tanks, fittings etc. are pressure rated and all tanks storing air are metal

Disadvantages:
‚Äì Uses a good bit of space for 2 tanks
‚Äì It‚Äôs heavy
‚Äì Double the hoses / plumbing (but parts are much cheaper so probably a wash)
‚Äì Getting the original OPD valves off of propane tanks is NOT easy - no matter what the youtube videos say
‚Äì Everyone thinks your t-shirt cannon is propane powered (maybe an advantage). Folks want to know when we turn on the ‚Äúflame thrower‚Äù option, which sounds like a ‚Äúlot of fun‚Äù but I‚Äôm sure wouldn‚Äôt meet the safety guidelines for our school football games.
‚Äì There are no water drains on propane tanks. Periodically we need to remove them and turn them upside down to drain all accumulated moisture out.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2021-07-12T21:24:34.558Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":113,"readers_count":112,"score":32.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":395022,"topic_slug":"t-shirt-cannon-help-maths","display_username":"Chadfrom7226","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":22056,"username":"msonnier","name":"Mentor FRC 2992, FTC 25619, past FTC 10337, FTC 14374","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/msonnier/{size}/199751_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20021,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/t-shirt-cannon-help-maths/395022/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2961589,"name":"MrBasse","username":"MrBasse","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mrbasse/{size}/65032_2.png","created_at":"2021-07-12T21:27:44.468Z","cooked":"

We get 80-100 shirts at most. The only real issue we run into is during playoff games where air temps get low (30-40 degrees) the CO2 tends to freeze things up. Our tank is vertical to avoid dispensing liquid, but near vertical should work too. I think 45 degrees would be doable, maybe a little more. Either way the liquid would become gas in the low pressure tank, but regulator freeze ups are a very good possibility.

If you‚Äôve already planned for horizontal, I would go with air. Although I just realized how nice it is to not have to worry about water in our system‚Ä¶

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2021-07-12T21:28:48.303Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":116,"readers_count":115,"score":43.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":395022,"topic_slug":"t-shirt-cannon-help-maths","display_username":"MrBasse","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":20021,"username":"Chadfrom7226","name":"Chadfrom7226","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chadfrom7226/{size}/113429_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":16614,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC #3572"},"post_url":"/t/t-shirt-cannon-help-maths/395022/9","custom_user_title":"FRC #3572","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2961590,"name":"Gus Michel II","username":"GeeTwo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/geetwo/{size}/120962_2.png","created_at":"2021-07-12T21:29:24.141Z","cooked":"

‚Äì There are no water drains on propane tanks. Periodically we need to remove them and turn them upside down to drain all accumulated moisture out.

If you mounted the tanks with the opening at the bottom, you could put drain valves in the plumbing rather than the tank. You could even skip valves and arrange it so your air/CO‚ÇÇ supply becomes the drain when the supply is disconnected.

  1. a) Though it wasn‚Äôt my first choice, my team actually uses a custom welded low-pressure tank made out of a ~4"dia piece of steel pipe, capped on both ends, with custom 1.5" fittings welded on. That said, the tank was built in a commercial shop (one of our sponsors) and was professionally pressure tested to over 500psi, we never operate it over 100psi. Based on the size of the tank, I‚Äôd estimate its capacity to be somewhere in the range of 615 in3.

    b) PVC is rated for WATER pressure NOT air pressure, and the two are NOT the same. Air is significantly more compressible than water. Busting a PVC tank with 280PSI of water will get some things wet, busting a PVC tank with 280PSI of air is more akin to setting off a bomb, complete with shrapnel (look up the plastic air tank failures from a few years back if you don‚Äôt believe me, there were some pretty impressive explosions at only ~150psi; thankfully I don‚Äôt think anyone was seriously hurt from those).

  2. We use 3000psi ‚Äú30-Minute‚Äù CFPV tank similar to this one. We were able to get ours used for free from a local company that tests and re-certifies such tanks. When we need them filled, we can go to one of two local fire departments (the closer department can fill them quickly to a lower pressure anytime, the other department can almost max them out but is less convenient to visit often). We have two tanks available to use at any given time, and one tank can usually get through an all-day event without any issues (whether it be a parade, demo, or other function) so we almost never swap them during an event. Your mileage may vary though, depending on barrel size and other factors (see below).

  3. Our system actually doesn‚Äôt use a hose, rather, the barrel, valve, and tank are all directly fitted together. The bottleneck of the system would be the 1.25" dia valve, in retrospect, we wish we had gotten a larger one. Flow is more important than pressure and a larger valve (higher flow rate) can allow you to lower your working pressure and save air, and/or improve shot distance.
    Another important factor here is the barrel diameter, as the smaller diameter the barrel also improves effective flow rate. In a prefect scenario, your barrel and valve/hose would be the same size, though obviously this is not usually practical, so do the best you can. We actually just moved to a smaller barrel diameter recently which has helped quite a bit.

  4. I‚Äôve never built a revolver-style shooter, but that said, I do know how having an under-sized projectile (thus, creating a gap for air to escape around) negatively impacts a shot, so my inclination would be to say that you should probably aim for the smallest gap possible. If I were to build such a system, I would probably design it such that it would actually create a seal with the barrel after it finished moving with some kind of mechanism, rather than allowing any gap.

GeeTwo:

On PVC: the problem with plastic tanks isn‚Äôt that they can‚Äôt be rated for the pressure. The problem is that if the tank ruptures, plastic will usually shatter whereas metal will tear.

I will take this moment to bring up my favorite t-shirt cannon fact: PVC shards don‚Äôt show up on an Xray image.
